div.p: Box 51/4, La Trobe Australian Manuscripts Collection, State Library of Victoria, Melbourne.

To proof.
MSS number needed.
Redmond Barry identified as addressee in M to W. Hooker, 29 January 1862 (in this edition as 62-01-29a).
A set of painted labels is provided for the timber specimens each label bearing at the back the number of the wood specimen to which it belongs. It may be found desirable to revarnish these labels in London, where under any circumstances at least a portion of the planks and sections should be polished. I would also suggest, that especially the broadest planks should be placed in such a way as to be seen to full advantage at the exhibition.
London International Exhibition, 1862. The timber specimens sent pr "Great Britain" continue the series of those forwarded by the "young Australia", bringing the number up to 437. All these are select specimens, which should not be used for fittings or be cut up for other purposes, but be left in their entirety for the exhibition. For fittings &c some additional pieces of wood are sent pr "Great Britain" and they are marked accordingly. A complete list of these timber is herewith submitted.
The list was not included in International Exhibition, London 1862 (1862), the standard catalogue of the exhibition, but was published in the catalogue of the Victorian Exhibition of 1861, which was preparatory to the London one; see Victorian Exhibition, 1861 (1861), pp. 225–46.

The framed wirenetting contained in Case No 5, Should
lower case s?
have been varnished, which might be done in England. These netting-frames as well as the leather covers fit into the saddlebags and are the simple apparatus used by me in exploring journeys for securing botanical specimens. These should after the exhibition be deposited in the Kew Museum.
The net and cordage made of the fibre of Cyperus vaginatus is deserving of particular attention, the material proving very tenacious and being in vast quantity available.
The specimen of the platypus will be claimed by Dr. Backhaus's (the exhibitors) brother. The moss is intended as a substratum for the Australian fruits.

The stockwhips, hidegird &c as well as the two photographic views of the Echuca bridges will be claimed after the exhibition by E. Mertens Esq.
M's cousin Ernst Mertens? of London.

It may be found necessary, that some of the Gipps
Gyps? i.e. gypsum casts? fruit should undergo revision as regards painting before they are displayed at the exhibition. Since the glass cases provided for them are not sufficient to protect the whole of the gyps casts, I would strongly recommend that some additional cases may be made in London for securing the whole collection against dust & mutilation. And here I might suggest, that for the proper keep, off-dusting & cleaning of the articles and their labels an ampler provision should be made in London, than in Melbourne, where not few of the articles suffered and showed to disadvantage in consequence of the want of regular and efficient arrangements in these respects. It may be found necessary to have new labels printed for oils, resins, gums & many other articles, so as to secure uniformity.
It would greatly enhance the display of the fruits, if the unfinished (second) set of casts could be painted in London.

I cannot sufficiently urge, that the copious series of oils, which on my suggestion and from material furnished by myself were distilled by Mr Bosisto and Mr Johnson,
HC: is this Henry Johnson of 40th Regiment ? More likely the chemist William Johnson; see Gibbney & Smith.
should at home receive the fullest amount of attention. Mr Bosisto, to whom I pointed out the facility of distilling these oils on a large scale, wherever sawmills exist, calculates that the Gallon of some kinds could be procured at a cost of less than 6/ (six shillings!) If so, — as I have no doubt, — I cannot but anticipate, that ere long a great commerce will spring up in this article, since the material for it is available in boundless quantity. As lightening material, for varnished and medicinal purposes, also for dissolving india rubber for waterproof liquids &c &c these oils will prove highly useful as will be seen by the jurors reports. The price of the Indian Cajuput oil, so similar to our Eucalyptus oils, exceeds much that calculated for the latter. A few kinds are still under preparation and will with some other yet [...]
illegible.

articles be forwarded by one of the next clippers.
It will be necessary to provide also for these oils some additional glass-cases.

Mr Arnold
C. H. Arnold. will inform the Commissioners through myself by next overland mail, what is to be done after the exhibition with his five beautiful cases of Myall pipes. The sixth case, containing the transverse section of polished Myall wood is destined for Sir Will. Hookers Museum at Kew. I am most anxious that to the same grand national establishment should be rendered available after the close of the exhibition in London all the articles of our Class 2 & 3, a wish which is unanimously shared by those Commissioners, with whom I had occasion to consult on the subject. Mr Champs permission has been obtained for also placing the wood specimens, worked up at the Penal establishment into bookform, into the Kew Museum. The [...]
